title: 109_hr6045
content: The "James Zadroga Act of 2006" extends the deadline for filing claims for compensation under the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund of 2001 for individuals who were physically injured or killed as a result of the terrorist-related aircraft crashes of September 11, 2001. Section 405(a)(3) of the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act is amended to limit the filing of claims under the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund after December 22, 2003, with exceptions for individuals who were unaware of their physical harm within 5 years of the enactment of the amendment. The Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act amended Section 405(a)(3) to restrict claims under the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund after December 22, 2003. Exceptions include individuals who were unaware of their eligibility due to psychological harm from the terrorist-related aircraft crashes. Individuals who suffered greater physical harm than known when filing a claim under the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund, and only discovered the full extent of their injuries after filing but before the enactment of the new regulations, may still be eligible for compensation within a 5-year period. Individuals may be eligible for compensation if they first knew about physical or psychological harm from the 9/11 terrorist attacks after filing a claim, within a 5-year period. Individuals eligible for compensation may have suffered greater physical or psychological harm from the 9/11 terrorist attacks than initially known when filing a claim. The Special Master will determine if the full extent of harm was not known until after the enactment of this law. The Special Master will determine if the full extent of harm was not known until after the enactment of this law. SEC. 4. EXCEPTION TO SINGLE CLAIM REQUIREMENT: Amends the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act to allow a second claim under certain circumstances. SEC. 5. ELIGIBILITY OF CLAIMANTS SUFFERING FROM PSYCHOLOGICAL HARM. Amends the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act to include psychological harm as eligible for claims. Conforming Amendment expands eligibility to include psychological harm. SEC. 6. IMMEDIATE AFTERMATH DEFINED. SEC. 6. IMMEDIATE AFTERMATH DEFINED. Amends the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act to define 'immediate aftermath' as the period after the terrorist-related aircraft crashes of September 11, 2001, with a demonstrable risk of physical or psychological harm to claimants.
